# Comprehensive Gene Program Analysis of Astrocytoma-Relevant Genes: Molecular Pathways Driving Glial Transformation and Brain Tumor Microenvironment Remodeling

This report presents a systematic literature-based functional analysis of 201 genes with relevance to astrocytoma pathobiology. Through integration of established astrocyte biology, extracellular matrix dynamics, and tumor microenvironment signaling, we identify eleven interconnected gene programs that collectively orchestrate glial cell transformation, metabolic reprogramming, synaptic dysfunction, and invasive phenotypes characteristic of astrocytomas. These programs encompass glutamate transport dysregulation, calcium signaling perturbations, extracellular matrix remodeling, enhanced cell migration capacity, metabolic coupling disruption, and reactive astrocyte activation—pathways that collectively establish the molecular and cellular foundations of astrocytic tumor initiation and progression.

## Astrocyte Biology and Normal Physiological Functions

Astrocytes represent the most abundant glial population within the central nervous system and perform diverse physiological functions essential for proper neural circuit function, synaptic transmission, and brain homeostasis[6][51]. These cells maintain the extracellular microenvironment through regulation of ion concentrations, water balance, and metabolite clearance, while simultaneously providing trophic support to neurons and regulating blood-brain barrier integrity[51]. The astrocyte-neuron lactate shuttle hypothesis, though recently challenged in certain in vivo contexts, has traditionally emphasized the role of astrocytes in glucose metabolism and lactate production, particularly under conditions of neuronal activity[48][51]. Contemporary understanding reveals that astrocytes engage in complex metabolic processes including tricarboxylic acid cycle activity, glycogenolysis, and pyruvate carboxylation beyond simple glycolytic function[51]. Additionally, astrocytes maintain critical roles in synapse formation, synaptic transmission modulation, synaptic plasticity, and plasticity through gap junction communication with oligodendrocytes and intimate association with the astrocyte-neuron-vascular unit[51]. The spatial organization of astrocytic endfeet around blood vessels and synaptic elements positions these cells at crucial nodes of neurovascular and metabolic coupling.

## Astrocytoma Development and Pathological Transformation

Astrocytomas represent glial tumors derived from astrocytic lineage cells and constitute a significant subset of central nervous system neoplasms with considerable heterogeneity ranging from lower-grade infiltrative lesions to highly aggressive glioblastomas[30]. The transformation of normal astrocytes into tumor cells involves accumulation of genetic alterations and progressive dysregulation of normal homeostatic functions[30]. Key molecular features include mutations affecting cell cycle checkpoint genes such as CDKN2A/CDKN2B and TERT promoter alterations[30]. Beyond genetic mutations, astrocytomas exhibit profound transcriptional reprogramming and altered cellular signaling that disrupts normal astrocyte physiology, enhances proliferative capacity, reduces differentiation constraints, and promotes invasive capabilities[4]. Critically, the tumor microenvironment undergoes dramatic remodeling involving dysregulation of extracellular matrix composition, altered vascular signaling, aberrant metabolic coupling, and enhanced neuroinflammatory responses[4]. The role of the astrocytic origin in glioblastoma development has been established through genetic lineage tracing studies demonstrating that loss of tumor suppressors such as CDKN2A/CDKN2B can drive GBM formation from astrocytes[52].

## Gene Program 1: Glutamate Transport and Synaptic Homeostasis

The first major gene program encompasses genes mediating glutamate transport, synaptic homeostasis, and excitatory neurotransmission. Astrocytic glutamate uptake through the excitatory amino acid transporter EAAT2 (encoded by SLC1A2) represents one of the most critical astrocyte functions, maintaining extracellular glutamate within physiological ranges and preventing excitotoxic neuronal damage[11]. The glutamate receptor genes GRIK1, GRIA1, and GRIA4 encode ionotropic glutamate receptors expressed on neurons and glial cells that mediate rapid synaptic transmission and calcium influx[37]. GRID2 encodes the delta-type glutamate receptor with specialized roles in cerebellar synaptic plasticity. Dysregulation of this program in astrocytomas results in reduced glutamate buffering capacity, aberrant glutamate receptor signaling, and disruption of synaptic transmission fidelity. Supporting this interpretation, recent studies document dysregulated expression of glutamate transporters and receptors in glioblastoma and other glial tumors[6][35]. The cation-chloride cotransporter SLC8A1 (sodium-calcium exchanger) participates in calcium extrusion and synaptic transmission modulation. Complementary genes including NOVA1 (neuronal-specific RNA-binding protein regulating alternative splicing) and CPEB2 (cytoplasmic polyadenylation element binding protein) regulate post-transcriptional control of synaptic proteins including GRIA and GRIN genes[35]. Furthermore, PPP2R2B (protein phosphatase 2 regulatory subunit) and PRKG1 (protein kinase G) regulate phosphorylation cascades affecting receptor trafficking and synaptic strength. Dysregulation of this program in astrocytoma impairs normal synaptic transmission and contributes to neuronal dysfunction within the tumor microenvironment.

## Gene Program 2: Extracellular Matrix Deposition and Stromal Remodeling

A second major gene program governs extracellular matrix deposition, organization, and remodeling—processes fundamentally altered in astrocytomas and glioblastomas. This program encompasses numerous collagen genes including COL1A2, COL5A2, COL23A1, COL25A1, and COL28A1, which collectively contribute diverse structural and signaling functions to the tumor stroma[4]. The laminin genes LAMA2 and LAMB1 encode basement membrane components critical for vascular stability and cellular adhesion. POSTN (periostin) serves as a matricellular protein modulating cell-matrix interactions and often upregulated in tumor stroma. Several genes regulate extracellular matrix proteolysis and remodeling: ADAMTS9 and ADAMTS9-AS1 encode metalloproteases with roles in proteoglycan degradation and matrix turnover, while TIMP-encoding genes (implied through pathway context) would function as protease inhibitors[38]. The metalloprotease inhibitor and regulatory genes including HTRA1 participate in matrix protein processing and proteostatic control. FBN1 (fibrillin-1) provides structural scaffolding and regulates TGF-β signaling through latent TGF-β binding[14]. Notably, this program exhibits profound dysregulation in astrocytomas and glioblastomas, with enhanced ECM deposition contributing to tumor stiffness, altered biomechanical properties, and modified growth factor sequestration[4]. Enhanced expression of matrix metalloproteinases such as ADAMTS genes facilitates tumor cell invasion through ECM barriers.

## Gene Program 3: Cell-Cell Adhesion and Migration Dynamics

A third gene program encompasses cell adhesion molecules and regulatory factors governing epithelial-mesenchymal transition-like processes crucial for tumor cell migration and invasion. This program includes multiple cadherin genes (CDH6) mediating homotypic cell-cell adhesion, while protocadherin genes PCDH7, PCDH9, and PCDH17 provide more specialized adhesion functions[10]. FAT3 encodes a large cadherin family member with roles in cell polarization and migration. Importantly, ZEB1 (zinc finger E-box binding homeobox 1) encodes a transcriptional repressor that drives epithelial-mesenchymal transition by suppressing E-cadherin and promoting N-cadherin expression, thereby facilitating migration and invasion[32]. CHL1 (cell adhesion molecule L1) mediates neuron-glia interactions and axon guidance. The complementary adhesion and junctional proteins including DLG1 (discs large homolog 1) maintain tight junction integrity. ARHGAP genes (ARHGAP6, ARHGAP18, ARHGAP26) encode GTPase-activating proteins regulating Rho family GTPases essential for cytoskeletal dynamics and cell migration. Complementary Rho regulatory proteins including RHOJ, VAV3, and STARD13 modulate GTPase activity and enable rapid morphological changes. The junctional protein JPH1 and desmoplakin-related proteins support intercellular adhesion. Dysregulation of this program in astrocytomas promotes partial epithelial-mesenchymal transition-like transitions, reducing intercellular adhesion, enhancing migratory capacity, and facilitating local invasion into surrounding brain parenchyma. This program operates in coordination with matrix metalloproteinase upregulation to facilitate proteolytic invasion through tissue barriers.

## Gene Program 4: Ion Channels, Transporters, and Electrolyte Homeostasis

The fourth major gene program encompasses ion channels and solute carriers governing electrolyte homeostasis, calcium signaling, and plasma membrane potential. SLC1A2 and SLC1A3 encode the glutamate transporters EAAT2 and EAAT1 responsible for glutamate clearance. SLC8A1 encodes the sodium-calcium exchanger mediating calcium extrusion. SLC4A4 encodes sodium bicarbonate cotransporter 1 (NBCe1) regulating acid-base balance and cellular pH[11]. Multiple potassium channel genes including KCNE4 and other KCNIP genes regulate potassium homeostasis and membrane excitability. SCN7A encodes sodium channel 7 contributing to membrane potential dynamics. The voltage-gated calcium channels including CACNA1c mediate calcium influx and excitation-contraction coupling. TRPM3 encodes a transient receptor potential ion channel with polymodal sensory properties. The ryanodine receptor RYR3 mediates calcium-induced calcium release from intracellular stores. TPCN1 encodes a two-pore calcium channel regulating lysosomal and endolysosomal calcium signaling. Critically, dysregulation of this program in astrocytomas impairs normal electrolyte homeostasis, enhances aberrant calcium signaling, and disrupts normal cellular excitability patterns. Astrocyte calcium dysregulation represents a hallmark feature of reactive astrocytes and contributes to neurotoxic signaling cascades[6][51].

## Gene Program 5: Calcium Signaling and Intracellular Calcium Dynamics

A fifth gene program encompasses calcium signaling machinery, intracellular calcium release, and calcium-dependent transcriptional regulation. ITPR2 encodes inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptor type 2, a calcium channel at mitochondria-associated ER membranes critical for calcium transfer into mitochondria[34][51]. STIM1 encodes stromal interaction molecule 1, a calcium sensor triggering store-operated calcium entry through ORAI channels. The voltage-gated calcium channels CACNA1c represent L-type channels mediating sustained calcium signaling. TPCN1 encodes two-pore calcium channels in acidic compartments. PPP2R2B encodes regulatory subunits of protein phosphatase 2A participating in calcium-dependent dephosphorylation cascades. PRKG1 encodes cGMP-dependent protein kinase mediating nitric oxide-dependent signaling. Calcineurin (implied through pathway context though NFATC1 related genes present) regulates nuclear factor of activated T-cells (NFAT) and orchestrates calcium-dependent transcriptional programs[51]. Dysregulation of this program in astrocytomas drives aberrant calcium oscillations, disrupts metabolic coupling between calcium signaling and glycolytic activity, and promotes transcriptional programs associated with reactive gliosis and neuroinflammation. Research demonstrates that calcineurin/NFAT pathway dysregulation contributes to astrocyte reactivity and reduced glutamate uptake in disease contexts[51].

## Gene Program 6: Metabolic Remodeling and Energy Substrate Utilization

The sixth major gene program encompasses metabolic enzymes and metabolic regulators governing glucose utilization, lipid metabolism, and energy homeostasis. BCAT1 encodes branched-chain amino acid transaminase 1, which regulates branched-chain amino acid metabolism. PDE genes (PDE3A, PDE4D, PDE7B, PDE8B) encode phosphodiesterases degrading cAMP and cGMP, thereby modulating metabolic signaling and energy sensing. ACSS3 encodes acyl-CoA synthetase short chain family member 3, activating short-chain fatty acids for metabolic incorporation. LPL (lipoprotein lipase) catalyzes triglyceride hydrolysis, mobilizing lipid substrates for energy. ELOVL2 encodes elongation of very long chain fatty acid protein 2, regulating polyunsaturated fatty acid elongation. ESRRG encodes estrogen-related receptor gamma, a nuclear receptor governing oxidative metabolism and mitochondrial biogenesis. Complementary metabolic regulators including HIF1A and HIF3A encode hypoxia-inducible factors promoting glycolytic metabolism under oxygen limitation[34][51]. The glycolytic enzyme regulations and metabolic checkpoint control through CDK6 and related regulators govern cell cycle progression coupled to metabolic capacity. Critically, astrocytomas exhibit metabolic reprogramming favoring enhanced glycolytic flux and reduced oxidative phosphorylation—the Warburg effect characteristic of cancer[26][51]. Tumor astrocytes may preferentially utilize glutamine through anaplerotic pathways and exhibit altered lactate metabolism[51]. This metabolic reprogramming serves dual functions: enhanced biosynthetic capacity for rapid proliferation and suppression of differentiation signals dependent on oxidative metabolism.

## Gene Program 7: Mitochondrial Function and Metabolic Coupling

The seventh gene program encompasses mitochondrial proteins and metabolic coupling machinery linking energy availability to cellular signaling and gene expression. MT-ND3 encodes mitochondrial NADH dehydrogenase subunit 3, a core component of respiratory complex I essential for oxidative phosphorylation. The noncanonical mitochondrial functions of connexin 43 (encoded by GJA1, gap junction protein alpha 1) represent emerging discoveries: astrocytic mitochondrial Cx43 directly inhibits isocitrate dehydrogenase 3α (IDH3α), thereby sustaining glycolytic metabolism and lactate production essential for neuronal excitability[26]. This mechanism operates independently of gap junction intercellular communication, identifying a novel mitochondrial scaffold function. The calcium uniporter machinery (MCU family) mediates mitochondrial calcium uptake, with dysregulation contributing to mitochondrial dysfunction and senescence induction through calcium accumulation and permeability transition pore activation[34]. STIM1 and related calcium sensing molecules regulate calcium-dependent mitochondrial function. Notably, metabolic coupling between astrocytes and neurons through the astrocyte-neuron lactate shuttle involves coordinated mitochondrial function in both cell types[26][51]. Dysregulation of mitochondrial function in astrocytomas impairs metabolic coupling with neurons, reduces lactate availability for neuronal oxidative metabolism, and promotes mitochondrial dysfunction-driven inflammation through inflammasome activation.

## Gene Program 8: Synaptic Plasticity and Neuronal Interaction

The eighth gene program encompasses genes governing synaptic plasticity, dendritic complexity, and neuron-astrocyte interactions. GRIN1, GRIN2A, and GRIN2B encode NMDA receptor subunits mediating calcium-dependent synaptic plasticity and learning[37]. GRIA1, GRIA2, and GRIA4 encode AMPA receptor subunits underlying synaptic strength and long-term potentiation. GRID2 encodes delta-type glutamate receptors with specialized plasticity roles. DPP6 (dipeptidyl peptidase-like 6) modulates Kv4 potassium channel function and regulates A-type potassium currents mediating action potential backpropagation essential for plasticity induction[35]. The postsynaptic density scaffolding protein DLG1 anchors receptors and signaling proteins at synapses. NOS1AP encodes nitric oxide synthase 1 adaptor protein modulating nitric oxide signaling and calcium-dependent plasticity. CNTNAP3B encodes contactin-associated protein, a presynaptic adhesion molecule. EYA2 (eyes absent homolog 2) regulates synaptic architecture through transcriptional control. TOX (thymocyte selection-associated high mobility group box) encodes a transcription factor governing neuronal gene expression programs. NPAS3 (neuronal PAS domain protein 3) regulates circadian-regulated gene expression in neurons[35]. Dysregulation of this program in astrocytomas disrupts synaptic plasticity, impairs long-term potentiation and depression mechanisms, and contributes to cognitive dysfunction observed in patients with brain tumors affecting cortical networks.

## Gene Program 9: Reactive Astrocyte Activation and Neuroinflammatory Responses

The ninth gene program encompasses genes characteristic of reactive astrocyte transformation and associated neuroinflammatory signaling. This program includes classical reactive astrocyte markers and transcriptional regulators: GFAP (glial fibrillary acidic protein) represents the canonical astrocyte marker with pronounced upregulation upon activation[2][6]. The transcription factor genes including SOX9 (implied through pathway context) and other lineage-defining factors control astrocyte identity. NOS2 (nitric oxide synthase 2, inducible NOS) produces nitric oxide promoting inflammatory responses and neuronal toxicity[31][49]. CNR1 encodes cannabinoid receptor 1 mediating neuroprotective signaling through endocannabinoid system activation, with reduced expression in activated astrocytes[18]. The complement cascade components and inflammatory mediators including TFPI (tissue factor pathway inhibitor) and related inflammation regulators modulate inflammatory responses. TNFRSF21 (TNF receptor superfamily member 21) participates in TNF-α signaling propagating inflammatory cascades. HOPX (homeodomain-only protein) marks a specialized astrocyte subtype with specific functional properties. RGS6 (regulator of G-protein signaling 6) regulates G-protein coupled receptor signaling potentially affecting responses to inflammatory mediators. The genes in this program exhibit dynamic upregulation during reactive astrocyte transition, with prominent activation in response to brain injury, neuroinflammation, and tumor development[6][31]. Research demonstrates distinct transcriptional modules within reactive astrocytes distinguishing pro-inflammatory neurotoxic A1-like astrocytes from more homeostatic neuroprotective A2-like astrocytes, with this program capturing elements of both phenotypes[6].

## Gene Program 10: Extracellular Matrix-Integrin Signaling and Mechanotransduction

The tenth gene program encompasses integrin-based mechanotransduction, cell-matrix adhesion signaling, and mechanically-regulated gene expression. Integrin family members including ITGB1 (integrin subunit beta 1) form heterodimeric adhesion receptors anchoring cells to extracellular matrix components[39]. The focal adhesion kinase-related genes and integrin-linked kinase (ILK) propagate integrin-dependent signaling cascades[42]. Cytoskeletal adaptor proteins including TLN2 (talin-2) link integrin cytoplasmic tails to actin cytoskeleton. FRMD4B (FERM domain-containing protein 4B) and related scaffolding proteins organize focal adhesions. RAP2-related proteins including ARAP2 (ArfGAP with RhoGAP domain protein 2) regulate Arf and Rho GTPases at focal adhesions. NTN1 (netrin 1) functions as a ligand for DCC and UNC5 receptors, promoting cell migration and axon guidance through integrin-independent mechanisms but often cooperating with integrin signaling[40][43]. The mechanotransductive signaling through YAP1 and TAZ (encoded by WWTR1) responds to mechanical stiffness and cell geometry through Hippo pathway regulation[24][27]. LATS2 (large tumor suppressor kinase 2) inhibits YAP1 within the Hippo pathway, with dysregulation in astrocytomas promoting YAP1-dependent tumor progression[27]. The mechanoresponsive transcription mediated through these factors governs gene programs responding to altered tumor microenvironment stiffness. Dysregulation of this program in astrocytomas promotes enhanced integrin signaling, mechanotransductive dysregulation through YAP1/TAZ hyperactivation, and cellular responses to altered ECM stiffness characteristic of tumors[4].

## Gene Program 11: Lipid Signaling and Phospholipid Metabolism

The eleventh gene program encompasses lipid signaling molecules, phospholipid-metabolizing enzymes, and lipid-dependent signaling cascades. DGKG and DGKZ encode diacylglycerol kinases catalyzing conversion of diacylglycerol to phosphatidic acid, modulating protein kinase C signaling. PLCE1 encodes phospholipase C epsilon, generating IP3 and diacylglycerol from phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate during GPCR signaling. The phosphoinositide signaling through inositol phosphate receptors (ITPR2) and related proteins governs calcium mobilization from ER stores. P2RY14 encodes nucleotide receptor P2Y14, a G-protein coupled receptor responding to extracellular nucleotides and lipid mediators. LPAR1 (lysophosphatidic acid receptor 1) responds to lysophosphatidic acid, a bioactive lipid mediating cell migration and inflammatory responses. DENND2A (DENN domain containing 2A) encodes a guanine nucleotide exchange factor for ARF family GTPases, regulating endosomal trafficking and lipid signaling organization. WIPF3 (WASp-interacting protein family member 3) participates in actin dynamics and membrane trafficking downstream of lipid signaling. The phospholipid-metabolizing enzymes and lipid signaling nodes in this program govern cellular responses to bioactive lipids, modulate receptor signaling, and coordinate cytoskeletal rearrangement with membrane trafficking. Dysregulation of this program in astrocytomas alters cellular responses to growth factor and inflammatory lipid mediators, enhances phospholipid signaling-dependent proliferation, and supports tumor-promoting metabolic and inflammatory phenotypes.

## Additional Genetic Complexity and Regulatory Networks

Beyond the major gene programs identified, several additional genes merit consideration for their specialized regulatory or contextual functions. The transcriptional regulators including ZEB1, TFCP2L1, ETV1, and HIVEP3 coordinate cell fate decisions and regulate lineage-specific gene expression programs. TFCP2L1 (transcription factor CP2-like 1) associates with pluripotency networks and potentially maintains stemness in tumor cells. ETV1 (ETS variant transcription factor 1) participates in growth factor-responsive transcriptional programs. MECOM (MDS1 and EVI1 complex loci protein) regulates gene expression in stem and progenitor populations. The long noncoding RNA genes including NEAT1, LINC01949, LINC01727, LINC02147, and others participate in chromatin regulation and transcriptional control through diverse mechanisms. NEAT1 (nuclear enriched abundant transcript 1) forms nuclear paraspeckles and regulates stress response gene expression. The antisense RNA genes including ADAMTS9-AS1, RORA-AS1, SLC8A1-AS1, NR2F2-AS1, and PCDH9-AS2 regulate cognate sense strand expression through antisense-mediated mechanisms.

Additionally, several genes participate in specialized cellular contexts and microenvironments. FREMND2 (FERM domain-containing protein 2) connects actin to membrane proteins. THSD7A (thrombospondin type 1 domain-containing protein 7A) participates in vascular formation and barrier integrity. SYBU (syntabulin) regulates vesicle dynamics and synaptic transmission. TMEM genes (TMEM154, TMEM108, TMEM178A, CCDC175) represent transmembrane proteins with diverse functions in membrane trafficking and signaling. Several genes function in metabolism of specialized molecules: TRMT9B encodes tRNA methyltransferase 9B participating in tRNA processing; CPNE4 encodes copine-4 regulating phospholipid binding and membrane dynamics; FIGN (fidgetin) participates in microtubule dynamics; ATP13A4 encodes an ATPase potentially involved in metal homeostasis. The metabolic enzyme ARSJ (arylsulfatase J) participates in sulfatide metabolism important for myelin. RPH3A encodes rabphilin-3A, regulating secretory vesicle docking. RTN1 (reticulon 1) participates in ER morphology and reticular network organization. The retinoid metabolism gene RBMS1 (RNA binding motif single stranded interaction protein 1) regulates RNA stability.

Several genes encode phosphatases and kinase regulators: PTN (pleiotrophin) represents a growth factor opposing heparin-binding EGF-like growth factor signaling in development and potentially in tumors. The protein tyrosine phosphatase genes PTPRG, PTPRJ, and PTPRZ1 regulate receptor tyrosine kinase signaling. PTPN14 (protein tyrosine phosphatase non-receptor type 14) represents a tumor suppressor frequently disrupted in cancers. The kinase regulatory genes control signaling output through phosphorylation dynamics. FKBP5 encodes FK506-binding protein 5, a chaperone regulating steroid receptor signaling and stress responses. SPRED1 (sprouty-related EVH1 domain containing 1) inhibits growth factor receptor signaling.

## Interconnections Between Gene Programs and Functional Implications for Astrocytoma

The eleven identified gene programs operate within interconnected regulatory networks yielding emergent cellular properties characteristic of astrocytomas. The glutamate transport program (Program 1) interfaces with calcium signaling (Program 5) through ionotropic glutamate receptors driving calcium influx upon glutamate receptor activation. Dysregulation of glutamate uptake through SLC1A2 impairment increases excitotoxic stress on neighboring neurons while aberrant astrocytic calcium signaling disrupts metabolic coupling with neurons. The extracellular matrix program (Program 2) and adhesion program (Program 3) collaborate to remodel tumor microenvironment architecture: enhanced matrix deposition through collagen and laminin synthesis combines with dysregulated cell-cell adhesion through ZEB1-driven epithelial-mesenchymal transition to facilitate local invasion. The ion channel program (Program 4) and calcium signaling program (Program 5) converge on calcium homeostasis dysregulation, with aberrant ion channel expression exacerbating calcium dysregulation and promoting reactive astrocyte transcriptional programs through calcineurin/NFAT signaling.

Metabolic reprogramming through Program 6 and mitochondrial dysfunction through Program 7 establish the basis for altered metabolic coupling with neurons. The noncanonical mitochondrial function of Cx43 maintaining glycolytic metabolism and lactate production represents a critical interface between astrocyte metabolism (Program 7) and neuronal support capacity. Synaptic plasticity dysregulation (Program 8) results from combined effects of impaired glutamate homeostasis (Program 1) and reactive astrocyte activation (Program 9), with reactive astrocytes potentially adopting pro-inflammatory neurotoxic phenotypes that impair synaptic transmission and plasticity. The reactive astrocyte program (Program 9) orchestrates transcriptional changes governing upregulation of neuroinflammatory mediators, reduced expression of neuroprotective factors like cannabinoid signaling (CNR1), and altered morphology and function characteristic of gliosis observed in tumors. The mechanotransductive program (Program 10) enables cellular responses to increased matrix stiffness and altered mechanical microenvironment of tumors through YAP1/TAZ-dependent transcriptional changes, potentially promoting proliferation and survival signaling. Lipid signaling (Program 11) coordinates with multiple programs through generation of bioactive mediators regulating cell migration (LPAR1), inflammatory responses (P2RY14), and calcium mobilization.

## Pathological Alterations Characteristic of Astrocytoma

The transformation of normal astrocytes to tumor cells involves systematic dysregulation across these interconnected programs. At the genetic level, common astrocytoma alterations include CDKN2A/CDKN2B loss reducing proliferative constraints, TERT promoter mutations enabling replicative immortality, and TP53 mutations impairing apoptotic safeguards[30]. These genetic events combine with transcriptional reprogramming that upregulates proliferation-associated genes while suppressing differentiation programs and normal astrocyte homeostatic functions. Transcriptomic analyses reveal enrichment of genes associated with EMT, reduced glutamate transporter expression, enhanced metabolic enzyme expression, and upregulation of reactive gliosis markers. The tumor microenvironment exhibits substantial extracellular matrix remodeling with altered collagen and proteoglycan composition, elevated levels of matrix-modifying proteases including ADAMTS enzymes, and modified growth factor sequestration through altered matrix protein expression[4].

Calcium homeostasis represents a particularly vulnerable node, with astrocytic calcium dysregulation promoting multiple pathological processes including glutamate uptake impairment, neuroinflammatory activation, altered metabolic coupling, and synapse dysfunction[51]. The reactive astrocyte programs operate along distinct molecular axes, with some astrocytes adopting pro-inflammatory neurotoxic phenotypes expressing elevated levels of NOS2, TNF-α, and IL-1β (supported by TNF and IL1B pathway context), while others maintain partial neuroprotective function. Recent evidence using temporal profiling of post-TBI astrocytes demonstrates that reactive astrocytes persist chronically with complex dual expression of both maladaptive neurotoxic genes and compensatory neuroprotective factors[6]. Metabolic reprogramming enhances glycolytic flux while reducing oxidative phosphorylation, similar to the Warburg effect in cancer cells, with consequent effects on biosynthetic capacity and tumor cell proliferation[26][51]. The altered metabolic coupling between tumor astrocytes and neighboring neurons impairs neuronal energy availability and may contribute to neuronal dysfunction and cognitive impairment in patients.

## Emerging Therapeutic Targets and Mechanistic Opportunities

Understanding the gene programs dysregulated in astrocytomas identifies multiple mechanistic targets for therapeutic intervention. Glutamate transporter upregulation through transcriptional or post-translational mechanisms might restore glutamate homeostasis and reduce excitotoxicity[11]. Calcium signaling modulation targeting aberrant ITPR2 or calcineurin/NFAT signaling pathways could normalize astrocyte reactivity and restore metabolic coupling[51]. Inhibition of the reactive astrocyte program, potentially through targeting NOS2 or inflammatory cytokine pathways, might reduce neurotoxic effects on surrounding neurons. Targeting YAP1/TAZ-dependent mechanotransduction through LATS2 restoration or direct YAP1 inhibition could suppress tumor proliferation driven by mechanotransductive signaling[27]. Matrix metalloproteinase inhibition targeting enhanced ADAMTS activity could reduce invasion capacity[38]. Metabolic interventions targeting glycolytic reprogramming or enhancing oxidative phosphorylation might impair tumor cell proliferation while restoring metabolic coupling with neurons. Lipid signaling pathway modulation, particularly targeting LPAR1 or related bioactive lipid receptors, could reduce migration and inflammatory responses.

## Conclusion

This comprehensive gene program analysis identifies eleven interconnected functional gene clusters governing astrocyte biology, tumor transformation, and microenvironment remodeling in astrocytomas. The gene programs encompass glutamate transport and synaptic homeostasis, extracellular matrix deposition and remodeling, cell adhesion and migration dynamics, ion channel and transporter function, calcium signaling, metabolic reprogramming, mitochondrial function and metabolic coupling, synaptic plasticity, reactive astrocyte activation, extracellular matrix-integrin mechanotransduction, and lipid signaling. Dysregulation of these interconnected programs through genetic mutations, transcriptional remodeling, and signaling alterations collectively establish the molecular and cellular foundations of astrocytic tumor initiation and progression. The identification of specific molecular targets within each program provides opportunities for mechanistic understanding and potential therapeutic intervention to restore normal astrocyte function or suppress tumor-promoting phenotypes. Future work integrating single-cell transcriptomics, epigenetic profiling, and functional validation studies will refine understanding of program-level dysfunction and identify optimal therapeutic combinations targeting multiple nodes within these networks.
